body:
@mboehm7 - this is only for consistency of printing out the values to `stdout`. According to the JIRA, `toString` should print out the matrix the same way that iterating over each element and using `as.scalar` would. Nothing more.

@deroneriksson - any thoughts?

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1834/

@nakul02 I can see that - what I'm saying is that this PR includes unnecessary changes (except the dense conversion case). Since sparse blocks will never contain negative zeros, there is no point in handling it when converting a sparse block to string. Also checks such as "!value.equals(0.0d) && !value.equals(-0.0d)" are unnecessarily convoluted and should be replaced with "value != 0".
@mboehm7 - fixed
Thanks for the review @nakul02.

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1836/

  • org.apache.sysml.test.integration.functions.data.FullReblockTest.testBinaryBlockSingeMSparseMR

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1837/
I'll go ahead and merge this tomorrow if there are no objections.

Hi @j143. Thank you for working on this.

You probably will need to be developing in an IDE such as Eclipse or IntelliJ in order to work on test classes such as this. The IDE will automatically alert you to syntax issues (currently Eclipse says that there are 6 syntax errors) and can also make it very easy to run the test classes in order to verify that they work. There is a lot of general information on the web that can be found regarding Eclipse/IntelliJ/Maven/Java, and most of this information applies to SystemML since it is essentially a regular Java project with a standard build system.

Tested with Pyspark (2.7):
`
from systemml import MLContext
ml = MLContext(spark)

Welcome to Apache SystemML!
Version 1.0.0-SNAPSHOT
ml.isStatistics()
False
ml.isExplain()
False
ml.setStatistics(True)
MLContext
ml.setExplain(True)
MLContext
ml.isExplain()
True
ml.isStatistics()
True
exit()
`

Other minor inconsistencies to be addressed separately.
Jenkins, skip ci

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1838/

Failed Tests: 1

SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/org.apache.systemml:systemml: 1

  • org.apache.sysml.test.integration.functions.data.FullReblockTest.testCSVSingeMSparseMR
@mboehm7 @dusenberrymw Could you have a look at this PR, and give some suggestions?

thanks @feihugis - just to clarify the modification of ParForProgramBlock is conceptually unnecessary because CachableData::export would only write if the matrix object is "dirty" (i.e., its in-memory representation differs from its hdfs representation), the write goes into a different file system, format, persistent write, or there are pending RDD operations. However, we recently changed the file scheme handling and the handling of pending RDD operations is non-trivial - so there might be internal bugs. Since this primitive is called from many different places, we should fix the internals and not try to patch it from outside. I don't have time tonight but can look into this tomorrow.

can you please hold off a few more days. Thanks.


Regards,
Berthold Reinwald
IBM Almaden Research Center
office: (408) 927 2208; T/L: 457 2208
e-mail: reinwald@us.ibm.com



From:   Deron Eriksson <notifications@github.com>
To:     apache/systemml <systemml@noreply.github.com>
Cc:     Subscribed <subscribed@noreply.github.com>
Date:   07/31/2017 12:10 PM
Subject:        Re: [apache/systemml] [WIP][SYSTEMML-1743] Create 
lightweight SystemML artifact (#578)



I'll go ahead and merge this tomorrow if there are no objections.
—
You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or mute the thread.

ok, I just did a quick test through spark_submit on a previous setup (with updated mnist_lenet_distrib_sgd.dml) and this run did not show any export issues on parfor. Maybe this is an issue of missing scratch_space cleanup in MLContext as pointed out a while ago (https://www.mail-archive.com/dev@systemml.incubator.apache.org/msg01665.html). @deroneriksson maybe we can simply delete the scratch_space on MLContext initialization and close (unless we already do it and I just missed it), which would still allow to pass variables between script invocations.

However, the script later ran into indexing issues with the parfor body (index range overflows the matrix dimensions on slicing out batches). @feihugis could you please double check the modified indexing expressions with input data that is unaligned with the batch sizes?

Thanks for reviewing @gweidner!
LGTM, i shall merge.

@mboehm7 Thanks for your help! The indexing expressions have been updated.  I'm guessing the reason you did not meet the export issues on parfor may be that the program exits before entering the export part due to the indexing issues. Could you test it again?
LGTM. Tested with Python 3.5.2 and Spark 2.1.0.
Thank you @deroneriksson for reviewing!
Test this Jenkins
ping @deroneriksson
ping @mboehm7

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1846/

This is very extremely useful Niketan! Thank you for such a great contribution. LGTM with a couple comments:

1) Could the Java MLContext.getHopDag methods be moved to static MLContextUtil.getHopDag methods (and include an MLContext method parameter too to get the various settings) and called from the Python MLContext?
  My thinking:
  a) Output is in Python graphviz format which is used from python but not java/scala.
      Example: `digraph {h5[label="u(print)[1:0-1:19]", shape="octagon", color="yellow", tooltip="[-1 X -1], nnz=-1, mem= [in=0, inter=0, out=0 -> 0MB]"];
rankdir = "BT"}`
  b) MLContext Java class is very lightweight by design (notice how few parameters tend to exist on the MLContext method signatures). The MLContextUtil class tends to hold such code so far in the API.

2) Nice to have:
  a) Javadoc all methods if they're in the MLContext API (public facing code).
  b) Auto-format the MLContext API Java code with one of SystemML's code formats (in dev/code-style)

The 'JavaPackage not callable' error was encountered when I used jvm_stdout prior to initializing MLContext.  For example:
`
from systemml import MLContext, dml, jvm_stdout
with jvm_stdout():
    ml = MLContext(spark)
    ml.execute(dml("print(\"Hello World!\")"))
`
or
`
from systemml import MLContext, dml, jvm_stdout, dmlFromResource
with jvm_stdout():
    script = dmlFromResource("/scripts/algorithms/LinearRegCG.dml")
`

With the change, the welcome message was visible in notebook similar to when first instantiating in pyspark or spark scala shell.

Welcome to Apache SystemML!
Version 1.0.0-SNAPSHOT
Hello World!
SystemML Statistics:
Total execution time:		0.001 sec.
Number of executed Spark inst:	0.

LGTM - thanks @dhutchis

@j143 thanks for working on this. However, this change only modifies the existing FunctionCallCP lop and hence you see all these test failures. Please, try to create a new lop FunctionCallSingleCP (or some better name) which follows the simple instruction generation of all the other lops (most importantly, you don't need to maintain the outputs anymore but simply take the provided output name from getInstructions(String[] inputs, String[] outputs)). Then also modify the FunctionOp by (1) adding a flag for single function invocations, and (2) conditionally on that flag compile either a FunctionCallCP or FunctionCallCPSingle on constructLops.

Well, as expressed before, adding more of such special case operators concerns me a bit. However, I think we should go ahead (and resolve this consistently for all these operations later). Could you please add a test case in org.apache.sysml.test.integration.functions.unary.matrix though (you could follow the template of LUFactorizeTest or QRFactorizeTest).
